title: Thursday, 26th November, 2015
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM

Morning

PM

Sorry a bit late

PM

And yeah we are completely distracted by the sensitive PEPs story

11:02 am
PM

Truth is we don't know whether these Barclays clients were Russian, or chinese or Latam or what

PM

I plump for Russian

PM

11:03 am
PM

Who knows?

BE

Well ......... 2011. Lots happening in and around the CIS.

PM

You can read the FCA final notice here: http://www.fca.org...-bank-nov-2015.pdf

11:03 am
PM

Suggest you start around page 9

BE

BE

11:04 am

"Landholdings, real estate and business and commercial activities" ...............

It's like the Linkedin entry for one of the Sopranos.

EDD is extensive fue diligence btw

ie, Google

BE

You pay lots of money and the bank doesn't ask you too many questions.

BE

Clearly, this steps beyond that .......

BE

Buying special safes to store the documents as far away from the legal database as possible, for example.

11:06 am

hehehe

PM

Extraordinary

11:07 am
BE

Yeah, and as Nichoman notes, the fine's quite low because the fee's comparatively low. It seems obvious that Barclays chased this deal too aggressively for the promise of follow-on business.

BE

And there's some weird stuff about Client A wanting money in spite of not being in on the deal, then being told that looked a bit too crook to go through without more paperwork, then changing his mind.

BE

As you say, it's all quite fascinating.

11:09 am

Actually, it goes on and on...

PM

At one point while arranging the Transaction, the Clients requested that
Barclays make a payment of several tens of millions of US dollars to a
third party. When Barclays questioned the rationale for that payment, the
request for the payment to be made to the third party was withdrawn.

PM

wtf?

11:09 am
BE

Joseph C says, via Slack ..... "Duh just realised. 2011. Arab Spring or Libya" .... Oh yeah. True.

PM

Quite possibly Assad.

BE

But we shouldn't speculate overly. Because we'll get down to specific names soon, and end up with a letter from Schillings.

11:10 am
PM

Don't think Assad's going to be suing me anytime soon

PM

But yeah, move on

undefined
11:10 am

PM

PM

11:11 am
BE

Mine too, but it was an unusually interesting Autumn statement.

BE

We should start with whiplash, I guess.

BE

And Son of Quindell.

11:12 am

Slater & Gordon shareholders will be going around in neck braces

PM

BE

Okay, so the proposal here is that whiplash doesn't qualify for general damages

11:12 am
PM

McCrummed

BE

Only special damages, including treatment and any loss of earnings,

BE

And claims sub £5k will be transferred to the small claims court.

11:12 am
BE

Fantastically, Slater & Gordon said overnight that its 2016 earnings will be unaffected.

BE

As in, before any law comes into force.

BE

That's satire.

11:13 am
BE

So anyway, the industry consultation is scheduled for 2016.

BE

Then in 2017 .... well, all of S&G's earnings disappear.

BE

Here's UBS

11:13 am
BE

The proposed changes, if implemented, could have a significant impact on SGH's UK operations in our view. SGH's recently acquired SGS division is primarily focussed on Road Traffic Accidents (RTA), providing legal services, motor assistance and health services. Based on our analysis, SGS services to RTA cases represents c90% of SGS, as such a significant amount of SGS earnings could be at risk. For FY17-18, we have reduced our EBITDA estimates by c44% and EPS estimates by greater than 50%.

BE

Understatement incoming.

BE

Given these potential legislation changes and our previously flagged concerns over FY16 guidance we do not expect the stock to outperform and maintain our Neutral rating.

11:14 am
BE

"we do not expect the stock to outperform" ......... Nope, fair.

BE

Valuation: PT reduced to $0.90
We have reduced our price target to $0.90 from $2.80. This reflects the change to our earnings estimates and a reduction in our assumption of reported EBIT conversion to free cash flow to 30% from 50% to reflect the increased level of regulatory risk.

BE

What none of that mentions is the rather pressing problem of S&G having no money.

11:14 am
BE

A reminder that S&G has net debt of A$623m at the current moment

BE

So let's be charitable and assume that falls to $550m by 2017.

BE

Which isn't an obvious assumption,as it's a business that's burning A$60m a year or thereabouts.

11:15 am
BE

But management is in jam-tomorrow mode, so let's believe them.

BE

That A$550m net debt now needs to be put against 2017 earnings of A$150m or thereabouts.

BE

Which doesn't look terribly good.

11:16 am
BE

S&G doesn't disclose debt covenants, oddly.

BE

But I'm thinking they're unlikely to be at ~4x EBITDA.

PM

Let's just remind ourselves how they've blown their own investors up

11:16 am
PM

BE

Yup. What Slater & Gordon needs now is a Slater & Gordon to buy it.

PM

hahah

11:17 am
PM

Yes!

BE

That's what rescued Quindell. But unfortunately, there are only so many Slater & Gordon's in the world.

BE

In fact, there will be one less quite soon.

11:17 am
BE

Here's Macquarie.

BE

We note the changes are still only proposed and have been released
pending a foreshadowed consultation process, however the intentions
appear clear and if implemented would be negative for SGH. The
proposals in our view appear to be a deliberate shift in strategy by a
Conservative Government to reduce cash compensation for minor RTA soft
tissue injuries. Proposed reforms appear to focus more on the treatment of
injury and if required, loss of earnings.

BE

The two key proposals to reduce the incentive to claim are i) the removal of
the right to general damages for minor soft tissue injuries, and ii) the increase
in small claims limit for personal injury claims from £1,000 to
£5,000. Furthermore, the government has proposed to increase funding to
fully digitise the small claims court which supports the goal of reducing soft
tissue claims costs. While specific outcomes remain uncertain ahead of the
consultation process, the changes proposed are significant and the most
material since LASPO reforms were implemented in 2012

11:18 am
BE

Given the timing, SGH does not expect any impact on FY16 guidance
but in our view FY17 case volumes are at risk for both Slater and Gordon
Solutions (PSD) as well as the pre-existing UK operations. The acquisition of
PSD has significantly increased SGH’s exposure to “at risk” lower value, lower
margin ‘high volume’ case load (high RTA exposure) as opposed to the higher
value, more complex (asbestos, medical negligence, etc.) multi track cases.
We estimate SGH's current UK PI revenue split for fast track /multi track is
c80%/20% respectively. We understand EBITDA margins achieved in multi-
track claims (25%) are close to double fast track claims (15%), which means
the earnings split is more even, but still favours the fast track business.

BE

No change to forecasts at this point. Earnings visibility is now low given the
regulatory overhang. We expect the stock to trade with a high degree of
uncertainty and at a significant discount to valuation based on current
earnings until it is resolved. PT reduced from $4.59 to $1.00

BE

The proposals put forward, if implemented, would in our view have a
significant impact on the earnings generation capability of the UK operations.
With over $650m net debt, SGH's balance sheet position in our view does not
afford much flexibility to withstand a significant earnings hit. Acknowledging
the heavy sell-off in recent days and the discount to our valuation based on
current earnings, we still see significant further downside if the reforms are
implemented. Rating reduced to Underperform

11:19 am
BE

A wee bit belated, that downgrade.

undefined
BE

Best stick to Autumn statement, I guess.

11:19 am
PM

guess so

BE

Because the buy-to-let side needs a moment or two, even though it's overdone territory.

BE

Terrible, trolling sob stories in the Mail this morning about middle-class parasitic dreams of becoming rentiers being shattered by the 3% stamp duty surcharge.

11:21 am
BE

Sellside, basically with one voice, saying "this won't make a difference".

BE

In fact it may even be positive.

PM

Five deck headlines in the Mail

11:22 am
PM

Our buy-to-let dreams are in ruins! Huge stamp duty rises for rental properties and second homes set to kill off booming market and scuppering plans of would-be landlords
Someone who buys a £500,000 second home will face a tax bill of £30,000
Experts said the move would ‘kill off’ property investment for savers
Money to be used to help first-time buyers and pay for affordable housing
Buyers pay no stamp duty on the first £125,000 of a property’s price

PM

http://www.dailyma...ooming-market.html

BE

Break out the nano-violins.

11:22 am
BE

Anyway, what it might do is to kick the threat of tougher limits on buy-to-let lending from the BOE down the road by a year.

BE

Or entirely, possibly, assuming we get a rate rise by mid 2017.

BE

Sector analysts all saying "buy sector, too cheap"

11:23 am
BE

Here's Gordon at Investec.

BE

OneSavings Bank shares are now down by 16% in a week. We believe that this has (in large part) been driven by speculation ahead of publication of the Financial Stability Report (1 Dec) and any regulatory action that may follow. Many investors ask which bank in our coverage has the greatest exposure to buy-to-let, to which our answer is OneSavings. However, as to what impact yesterday’s Autumn Statement has had on our earnings forecasts, the simple answer is zero. As such, we upgrade to Buy (from Hold); 375p TP unchanged.

BE

n his “tax-and-spend” Autumn Statement, Chancellor Osborne has (once again) used stamp duty as his primary weapon of choice. However, the specific measure announced – a new 3% stamp duty “surcharge” for buy-to-let properties and second homes targets a market segment which was already widely believed to be vulnerable to “cooling measures” of one form or another.

As the Chancellor acknowledges, a large part of the buy-to-let market, perhaps 70%, is cash funded, i.e. “un-banked”. As such, it would be wrong to suggest that his targeted £1bn p.a. additional tax-take will entirely fall on the economics of existing buy-to-let-financed rental properties. Over time, we expect further concentration in the professional/corporate end of BTL… and higher rents!

For OneSavings, we think the practical reality is very simple. Its overall pace of loan growth is constrained by capital, rather than by market size. We have previously cited that as a reason why loan growth is unlikely to “positively surprise” us. Equally, we argue now that its pace of loan growth is unlikely to decline. If this assumption is correct then yesterday’s sell-off was misplaced.

We do not know what (if anything) will happen on 1 Dec. The Bank of England previously cited the 8 July BTL “cooling measures” as grounds for inaction. It now has fresh reason to tread carefully for fear of unintended consequences.

OneSavings has lost its premium rating and now trades on 7.5x 2017e EPS. We upgrade to Buy (from Hold); 375p TP reaffirmed. We now see considerable value right across the sub-sector with Aldermore (Buy), Shawbrook (Buy) and Virgin Money (Buy) trading on 7.0x, 7.8x and 8.1x 2017e EPS respectively.

11:24 am
PM

Trader Gordon has been caught the wrong side of that

PM

have you seen some of these rabid stamp duty victirms tho bryce?

PM

11:25 am
PM

Heart bleeds

BE

Nice kitchen.

PM

11:25 am
BE

Not so nice kitchen.

BE

(No offence, if they're reading.)

BE

RBC?

11:26 am
BE

Thoughts from OneSavings Bank (OSB LN – 341.3p; Sector Perform, 405p price target):
l The increased rates of stamp duty only impacts purchases, not remortgage, which is an increasing part of the business.
l Capital appreciation over the longer term is a core motivation for many investors in buy-to-let, particularly “professional” landlords. Therefore the higher
stamp duty rate is unlikely to change the decision to invest for many. 
l The average loan-to-value on OSB’s buy-to-let mortgage book at H1/15 was 67%, with new originations averaging 72%, which offers scope to roll up the cost of
the additional stamp duty into the mortgage amount without compromising existing risk management policies.
l The stamp duty increase is unhelpful and creates uncertainty, but the positive fundamentals underlying the buy-to-let mortgage market (housing shortage,
increased demand for rental properties) remain intact.

BE

Thoughts from Aldermore (ALD LN – 243.9p; Outperform, 310p price target):
l The loan book is diversified - 60% of Aldermore’s lending is in asset classes other than buy-to-let.
l The Autumn Statement also announced a new London Help-to-Buy scheme and a new affordable homes programme which will support first time buyers.
Aldermore views these measures as an opportunity - 43% of its residential mortgage book is owner occupied.
l According to the Council of Mortgage lenders, ~50% of market origination is remortgage and therefore not subject to stamp duty. Aldemore’s remortgage
volumes exceed 50% of its originations.
l The average price of a buy-to-let property financed by Aldermore is £200k. The additional stamp duty incurred under the new rules would be an additional £5k
- £6k. Aldermore does not believe the quantum of additional transaction costs is enough to deter long term investors.

BE

Thoughts from Paragon (PAG LN - 376p; Sector Perform, 440p price target):
l The fundamental drivers of demand in the private rented sector (housing shortage, social and demographic change, increased preference for renting) remain
unaffected. While there may be some negative impact at the margin on buy-to-let volumes, Paragon does not believe that the supply side of the private rented
sector will be materially affected.
l Paragon does not believe that the 3% increase in stamp duty is enough to deter investors in buy-to-let, although the company acknowledges that the change is
unhelpful.
l Given the ongoing shortage of housing, underlying population growth and strong economic fundamentals, in Paragon’s view the stamp duty changes will have
an immaterial impact on house prices.

11:26 am
BE

Conclusion: Yesterday we concluded that the new stamp duty rules are negative for the companies in our coverage universe with exposure to buy-to-let, since it creates
uncertainty over how appetite to purchase rental properties and hence demand for buy-to-let mortgages will be affected. We continue to believe this is true, and
acknowledge that the measures could be a small negative for buy-to-let demand. However, as the comments from Aldermore, OSB and Paragon highlight, the stamp duty
changes are unlikely to change the decision of many to invest, particularly for those longer term investors seeking capital appreciation. Therefore, while we
acknowledge that the changes could reduce demand at the margin, we do not expect buy-to-let volumes to be materially affected over the longer term. Nevertheless, we
expect uncertainty around the sector to persist until at least 1-Dec, when the Bank of England’s Financial Policy Committee is expected to be granted powers to regulate
the buy-to-let market by the Treasury.

PM

This is Markets Live

Aldermore Group PLC (ALD:LSE): Last: 240.00, down 5 (-2.04%), High: 244.10, Low: 237.00, Volume: 283.30k

There are exciting projects in the Editorial pipeline for 2016, supported by our new owner. You'll be hearing more about these shortly from Lionel.

As a one-off celebration, the Christmas dinner/lunch subsidy of £30 a head will return this year for Editorial staff across the globe to share some cheer and goodwill with your team.

11:29 am
BE

BE

As for BHP, Caz downgrades.

BHP Billiton PLC (BLT:LSE): Last: 835.60, down 17.9 (-2.10%), High: 852.00, Low: 825.50, Volume: 5.40m
11:30 am
PM

(We might try and book http://www.miyama-...mayfair/index.htm)

BE

Divi not covered by cash.

BE

(Look at me, pressing on with the financial stuff while everyone else talks guff. I'm determined to earn my £30 a head lunch this year.)

11:32 am
BE

Here's Caz's front page.

BE

We believe the Samarco tailings dam failure will prove to be the straw that
breaks the camel’s back on BHP’s progressive dividend. At spot, assuming
$500m costs related to Samarco and aggregate FY’16-17E capex $2bn below
guidance, we estimate a ~$8bn shortfall to comply with A- credit metrics by
the end of CY’17E. With the risk of further downside to base metals, we
believe pressure will grow on BHP’s Board and we now forecast a 50% cut to
the progressive dividend at FY’16 results. Against that backdrop, we do not
believe 8% YTD underperformance vs RIO and +30-35% vs AAL/GLEN
adequately reflects the risk investors, particularly those with an income focus,
and we downgrade to Underweight with a revised Dec’16 PT of £7.50/sh.

BE

 Material cash/capital shortfall: On spot prices and assuming no change to
the US$6.6bn pa progressive dividend we estimate BHP faces a $16-20bn
capital shortfall to sustain its A+ credit rating and a cumulative ~$9bn
deficit of FCF vs dividend commitments for CY'16-17E. Even assuming
management is willing to tolerate an A- rating, which they have indicated is
below their definition of “solid A”, we estimate an $8bn capital shortfall,
despite our capex forecast sitting $2bn below guidance for FY’16-17E.

11:32 am
BE

 Factoring in a 50% dividend cut: In that context, with downside risk to
copper prices and with management commentary increasingly equivocal on
the trade-off between capital returns and investment in growth, we believe
BHP will ultimately rebase the dividend 50% lower (to ~US$3.3bn pa) at
FY’16 results next August. In combination with further reductions in
working capital, opex and capex, this should allow the company to manage
its balance sheet effectively, whilst still offering a ~4.5-5.0% yield.

BE

 Removing Samarco: We have removed Samarco from our model. While
NPV analysis suggests a likely justification for a restart, we believe the
environmental, political and social dimensions mean there is no certainty
that Samarco will regain its licence to operate. We make a preliminary
estimate of US$0.5bn (BHP share) in rehabilitation/fines over three years.

BE

 Downgrade to UW: We reduce our EPS by 7%/9%, respectively, for
FY’16/17E and NPV by 4%, with the company now on spot EV/EBITDAs
of ~10.5x, a ~5% premium vs RIO and a base case P/NPV of 0.69x (~25%
prem. to diversified peer group). We recalibrate our price target
methodology to a blended average of our base-case and spot valuation,
which reduces our Dec'16 PT to £7.50/sh (previously £13.00/sh). We cut our
recommendation to UW and retain our preference for RIO.

11:33 am
BE

Socgen saying similar.

BE

Update At BHP Billiton’s AGM in Perth last week, Chairman Jac Nasser reiterated that the
dividend ($6.5bn paid in FY15) is an outcome of appropriate capital management and that
the balance sheet must always come first (a strong single A rating is the target). With a
9.3% consensus dividend yield, BHP’s commitment to keeping its dividend stable or
gradually raising it is proving increasingly questionable and unaffordable in our view with:
1) a payout ratio of greater than 100% until 2019e; 2) FCF not covering the consensus dividend until
2018e; 3) a net debt increase looming; and 4) risks of credit-rating downgrades. We think it
is just a question of time before BHP unveils its new dividend policy (interim results in
February 16 or FY16 results in August 16) which could mean rebasing the dividend at a
level that is consistent with BHP’s sustainable cash flow capability or adopting a set pay-
out policy (very unlikely in our view). We assume the FY16e dividend will be cut by 50% to
$0.62, and this could happen at the interim results. Despite this, on our new numbers, our
FCF forecasts barely cover our lower dividend expectations in the FY16-18e period.

BE

SG view We have revised down our earnings expectations on the back of lower
commodities prices, and we have factored in the impact of the Samarco tragedy. Our new
EPS for FY16-18e $0.23 ($0.50), $0.37 ($0.67) and $0.66 are well below consensus.

11:34 am
BE

How we value the stock We reiterate our Hold rating on BHP Billiton with a lower TP of
915p (vs 1,050p) given our reduced estimates. Our TP is based on the weighted average of
our DCF base-case scenario (1,050p 70%) and a “spot” scenario (600p 30%, both using a
real WACC of 7.5% and modelling cash flows until the end of mine lives with no terminal
value). We have a 12m TSR of 9.2%. Given the current valuation (fwd P/E above 20x for the
next three years), we would expect any commodity price recovery to translate into a
multiples contraction, i.e. limited share price appreciation.

BE

Twenty times until 2019!

PM

That's not confident at all no the divi

11:34 am
PM

BE

Agree. Would be weird to see BHP cut before Anglo.

undefined

PM

Ophir top of the 250 list

PM

PM

BE

Ophir Energy PLC (OPHR:LSE): Last: 96.00, up 5 (+5.49%), High: 96.00, Low: 90.05, Volume: 1.73m
BE

So what can we say here?

11:37 am
BE

BE

Independent reports this morning ........

BE

Vague bid chatter boosted Ophir Energy by 6.4p to 91p, although the FTSE 250 oil firm claimed there was no truth to the rumours.

11:38 am
BE

Which is odd, as they were in no-comment territory to me yesterday.

BE

Perhaps they only speak to the Independent. Whatever, it's pretty clear that there's no statement required.

BE

As said previously, Ophir's talking about farm-ins to two fields

11:40 am
BE

Those talks head in all sorts of directions, as we've seen a lot. If the Panel's chilled enough not to require any kind of statement, I guess we should be too.

BE

UBS sent this out late yesterday ......

BE

We believe the bulk of Ophir's value lies in two unsanctioned, early-stage LNG projects
(Fortuna FLNG and Tanzania LNG) which it is looking to sell down. This sub-sector faces
challenges: volume (ample existing and proposed supply); cost (at a time of extreme
industry capital discipline); and, price (agreeing LT deals post the oil crash and with spot
attractive to buyers). Consensus is bearish, but we think longer-term LNG fundamentals
remain ok. Prospects for demand appear solid, near-term oversupply will eventually
clear and we see 80Mmtpa of unsanctioned new capacity (c.20 trains) trains needed by
2025E. It is plausible that an investor with a long-term view could see significant latent
value in Ophir.

11:41 am
BE

We see Ophir's LNG projects in Equatorial Guinea and Tanzania as almost 'option value'
in the current share price. Our NAV of the Asian (ex. Salamander) assets alone is
£0.93/sh. We carry Fortuna FLNG at £0.48-0.96/sh (risked-unrisked) and Tanzania LNG
at £0.32-0.40/sh. Our total commercial NAV is £1.70-2.42/sh. The company has made
good progress with Fortuna FLNG, confirming at this month's CMD volumes are well
oversubscribed and targeting full Sales & Purchase Agreements (SPA) in 1Q16, ahead of
F.I.D in mid-16 and first gas mid-19. Tanzania LNG is in something of a hiatus with the
BG-Shell deal expected to result in a change in operatorship next year, but let's not
forget this is a giant resource base (c.30TCF) and in November 2013 Temasek paid
Ophir $1.3bn for a 20% stake in the project (leaving Ophir with a residual 20% now).

BE

Valuation: target price set at 0.70x commercial NAV
Core: £0.65/sh; Commercial: £1.70/sh; RENAV: £1.76/sh.

PM

(QE2 -- do you really think this Worthington thing will come back? Seriously?)

11:42 am
undefined
BE

TalkTalk was yesterday's other bid rumour, of debatable quality.

Talktalk Telecom Group PLC (TALK:LSE): Last: 245.60, up 6 (+2.50%), High: 247.70, Low: 235.50, Volume: 1.15m
11:44 am
BE

Vodafone? Deutsche Tel? Li Kai Shing? Sure, all of those, or fewer, or none.

BE

Would Deutsche Tel be able to buy TalkTalk given its stake in BT? Dunno. Open question.

BE

Anyway, the more fundamental reason for TalkTalk being up today is a push from Macquarie.

11:45 am
BE

Recently we met with management during the post results roadshow and our conviction has been reinforced. We believe the underlying dynamics of the business are supportive
and the fallout from the cyber attack is manageable. Outperform with 46% TSR
to our target of 333p.

BE

 In our meeting with management, we have been reassured by five themes
that support our positive outlook:
 Management retain confidence in the direction of the business with the
focus on RGU growth (fibre, mobile and TV) in the residential business.
 There is an under appreciation of the B2B business, which is exploiting
the growth in Ethernet services as SMEs transition from legacy leased
line and voice services. The corporate segment delivered 7.9% revenue
growth in 2Q15/16.
 There is confidence in the economics of the company’s wholesale
consumer operation with OIBDA in-line (to slightly greater) with consumer
retail’s (on a per customer basis).
 We expect TalkTalk to be a beneficiary of increased regulatory pressure
on BT and any consolidation remedies from announced transactions.
 MTTS is on track and subject to limited impact from October’s cyber
attack; in our view, FY15/16 targets appear deliverable. We target a
FY15/16 OIBDA of £305m.

BE

Our estimates are unaltered. We continue to assume 50k broadband
customer loss in 2H 15/16 due to the cyber attack and only 40k TV additions.
We are 3-5% above consensus OIBDA estimates in FY15/16 and FY16/17
and secondly we assume 21% OIBDA margins in FY16/17 compared to
consensus at 20% and management’s target of 25%.

11:46 am
BE

As we've said a lot, it's never inaccurate to say Vodafone's looking at TalkTalk, but it's never terribly useful to say it either.

BE

There's a price at which TalkTalk's value (+ a 30% takeover premium) is smaller than its cost of customer acquisition. That changes daily.

BE

And I'd be surprised, given the uncertainties over the customer count and TalkTalk's big promotional investment into MVNO, if the numbers add up right now.

BE

11:52 am
BE

Multiples remain challenging for AO especially in light of likely short-term operating losses. Whilst the FY2016F EV/EBITDA may cause readers to do a double take, this is against a wafer thin level of earnings we project for the current financial year. However, the following two financial years we expect to see the EV/EBITDA normalise, to c65x FY2017F and c24x FY2018F. Our bullish stance is predicated on the belief that AO can execute its strategy across Europe and display consistency in profitability in the long-term. Our discounted cash flow analysis leads to an intrinsic value of the stock of 170p. Our projections remain prudent and there is possible upside from the addition of other territories (existing trading territories are included in our valuation; UK and Germany).

BE

The market in our view has perhaps reacted in a knee-jerk fashion to yesterday’s statement with the investment currently running through the income statement amplifying the impact of losses against a business previously operating from a low profit base. We believe yesterday’s share price weakness presents an opportunity for investors to gain exposure to a business:

· Engaged in a high growth segment of online retail.

· With a management team committed to a long-term strategy to become a key online retailer for electricals in Europe.

· With a wide scale opportunity to expand the business into new markets (both in terms of territories and product categories) without the need for material capital expenditure whilst leveraging existing assets.

· With an outstanding customer service proposition, underpinned by a top-class logistics operation, which differentiates AO from many of its peers.

· The strategic comfort of a strong balance sheet; with c£31.0m of net cash on the balance sheet for FY2016F.

Here's Numis to summarise.

BE

A disappointing set of results/news. Continuing net revenue at £52m missed our
£55m estimate, partly reflecting a decrease in prepaid electricity consumption. PBT
was just £3.2m vs. -85% vs. our estimate of £21.9m, reflecting another significant
write down in the value of M&O which management did not manage to sell in H1
as planned (now planned for H2 at a lower price) and the collect+ JV swinging
back into loss reflecting courier cost increases. Excluding the goodwill writedown,
PBT was £21.4m, slightly below our £21.9m estimate. The dividend at 14.2p was 3%
higher than our 13.8p estimate, reflecting a higher payout ratio. We would anticipate
downgrading our earnings forecasts to reflect weaker underlying trading, further M
+O/Collect+ losses, possibly partly offset by some cost reductions, albeit we expect
to increase dividend forecasts (reflecting an apparent willingness to increase the
payout ratio).

BE

● Numbers: Continuing net revenue was £52.3m (our est. £54.5m), explained as bill/
gen £26.2m (£28.5m), topups £11.1m (£11.1m) and retail £15.1m (£14.9m). PBT was
£3.2m (£21.9m), explained as D&A -£2.9m (-£3.2m), other CoS -£5.4m (-£5.5m),
admin costs/M+O losses -£23.3m (-£24.4m), collect+ JV -£0.4m (+£0.5m), further write
down in M+O value -£18.2m (not expected) and net interest +£0.0m (+£0.1m). DPS
was 14.2p (13.8p).
● M&O: Management said "Offers on the Online Payments business have not met
expectations and accordingly, we have impaired the entire goodwill on this business."
The balance sheet value is now £36m, having previously been written down to £55m
and compares to the minimum £53m (acquisition prices paid only, i.e. not including
management time, subsequent investment, time value of money, etc.) the company
paid for those businesses.
